title: What level of self-driving is Tesla? - Quora

response.answer_text: It doesn’t quite fit any of the standard “levels”…and the exact description of those levels varies between descriptions. Let’s go with my first google hit here:  Level 1 is cruise control. Practically 100% of modern cars have that. Level 2 driving is very easy. Level 2 is where the vehicle controls steering and acceleration/braking under simple circumstances and the human has to be ready to take control. Tesla certainly manages this…but so do many other cars with “lane centering steering” and “augmented cruise control”. Level 3 vehicles are a bit odd. “The driver is a necessity” - but “is not required to monitor the environment”…but must “be ready to take control of the vehicle at all times with notice”. So…eh? What this seems to be saying is that the car does drive itself - you can play games on your cellphone while it’s driving - but you have to be ready to take control if the car beeps at you or something. So this imagines a car that KNOWS when it can’t drive and tells you long before it fails to drive correctly. Time for you to drop the cellphone, look around you - assess what traffic is nearby and what speed the AI is taking you - and THEN take control before the AI panics and gives up. That’s an odd sort of a car. One that’s detected that it can’t cope and needs a human…yet can maintain control for the time it takes for the human to take over when they aren’t paying attention to the road. That’s weird….I can’t imagine a car like that…and Tesla can’t do that. If there is a situation where the Tesla AI can’t cope - you have to take over RIGHT NOW!!! Level 4 gets more controversial. Level 4 vehicles don’t need human interaction “under certain conditions”…but evidently a human still has to be there for those other not-certain-conditions. But my Tesla can self-drive across a parking lot without a human involved. I don’t even have to be sitting inside the car. This does fit what Level 4 demands…the car completely self-drives and the human is only there in case of an emergency…so you could argue that Tesla does that. So does a parking lot qualify as “under certain conditions”? If you think it does - then Tesla is Level 4 but not Level 3 ?!? Truth is - that in almost all driving situations, you need a human. Level 5 means the car literally drives itself, everywhere, no human intervention required whatever. There are no Level 5 cars out there - and Tesla isn’t even close. So I dunno…Level 2 or Level 4 but not Level 3. CONCLUSION: I don’t think this “levels of autonomy” scale is at all useful. If you want to get all hard-core over it - you’d say that Tesla is EITHER level 2 or level 4. But it’s CLEARLY ***WAY*** better than any other level 2 car on the road - it’s not even comparable. Tesla’s can overtake, stop at stoplights and signs, slow down in school zones, change lanes to get you to the right freeway exit. Handle roadworks that have coned off lanes…comparing that to a car that can stay in the center of it’s lane and not rear-end the car in front is ludicrous. But then the Level 3 description gives no credit for all of those things and allows a crappy Level 2 car to pass the test if it can merely say “I give up” with 10 second’s notice. Level 4’s allowance of only needing to drive without a human in some circumstances gives Tesla a passing grade if those circumstances include ONLY driving in a parking lot at 5mph or less. Sorry - but that scale is essentially useless for any purpose I can imagine. Basically, level 2 is very easy to attain, level 5 is virtually impossible - and levels 3 and 4 are too much of a mess to really mean anything.

Short answer is Level 2. Allow me to expound on that. SAE International defines autonomous driving at 6 levels (Level 0 - Level 5):  Tesla is currently at Level 2, and is close to Level 3 for travel on limited access highways. To be Level 3, which will allow the human driver to take his hands off the wheel and divert attention away from the road, Autopilot will have to anticipate situations in which it will need assistance, and give reasonable advanced warning to the human driver to take over (i.e., within a few seconds). So for, example, Level 3 Autopilot will pass control to the human driver when weather conditions deteriorate, a road construction zone is detected, an emergency vehicle is approaching, or the car is exiting the expressway onto secondary road infrastructure, to mention a few. Level 3 Autopilot will have to handle things that happen with little or no warning, like braking for an animal crossing the road, steering away from another vehicle to avoid a collision, or detecting and driving around a pothole. Elon Musk has stated at Tesla’s Investor Autonomy Day (April 2019) that Autopilot will be “feature complete” for full self driving by the end of the year. It’s not clear what that means exactly. It seems reasonable to expect that when Autopilot 3.0 hardware and FSD software is released this year or early next, Autopilot will advance to Level 3 for interstate highway travel. That would be a huge accomplishment for Tesla, putting them clearly in the lead for bringing autonomous cars to market for general use. Tesla will not be able to build out the Tesla Network of ride hailing robocars until Autopilot Level 4 is in the bag and regulators approve its deployment. To get to SAE Level 4 will require many millions of miles of shadow mode testing of the new hardware and software, plus months of incremental improvements, and, of course, regulatory approval based on solid statistical evidence that the system meets acceptable safety and reliability standards which probably don’t even exist yet. Several states have already passed legislation to allow self driving cars to operate on public roadways provide they meet certain requirements. For example, as of July 1, 2019, Florida allows self driving cars to operate throughout the state as long as the owner of the car carries one million dollars of liability insurance. That’s a formidable requirement. However, at the same Investor Autonomy Day presentation, Elon Musk speculated that Tesla would be liable for costs incurred from accidents in which Autopilot was determined to be at fault. So much is happening these days in the development of autonomous vehicles. It’s going to have a huge impact on the way we live in just a few short years.
